posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

"I've been considering switching from 6 AWG wires to 4 AWG wires next season. Almost made the change this season, but decided against it because the effort required to make the switch, such as reworking the charging setup, outweighed the benefits we would have gained. I'd like to know why your teams use 4 AWG and if the effort it took to switch, like reworking your charging setup, was worth it for you."

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: At the championship, @sdtrent presented his team's experience, which is worth reading or watching. He shared this in another topic on CD (Chief Delphi).

posts.name: Battery Nerd - FRC #4561
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the mention about the seminar! @MetabolicCloth and @elctrilica, the link below includes notes on our journey of switching to larger wire size while keeping the SB50 connectors intact for all of our SB50 connected chargers, testers, and other equipment. This process involves important considerations, such as attention to detail when trimming the 2ga cable to fit the system terminals, and there’s a notable cautionary tale involving the PDH (Power Distribution Hub). Additionally, there’s a write-up available on switching to 2ga with SB50 connectors. Below, you’ll find links to a Google Doc with more details, a presentation titled "Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance," and a video presentation on the same topic. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions about our approach or experiences. Thanks again!  

Shane

link_counts.title: 2ga Battery Cables and TerrorByte Terminals - Google Docs
Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance - Google Slides

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: It’s somewhat difficult to gauge for us this year since the power demands on our 2025 robot are significantly less than our 2024 robots were. That being said, we switched over to 4AWG while still using the Anderson SB50 connectors for compatibility with older hardware, following the instructions outlined in this paper: *Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics*. In general, the 4AWG seems to be much more robust and results in a lower resistance of the system overall. Additionally, modifying only the Anderson lugs for the batteries is somewhat cheaper than replacing all your SB50s (which includes Batteries, Chargers, and Robots). However, it would take a more power-taxing game to fully assess how much this improvement enhances performance.

link_counts.title: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked: Does your power wire feel hot to the touch after a match? If yes, it's time to upgrade your wiring.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
4 AWG is the biggest that doesn’t require a lot of extra work. It feels like the right price/performance/annoyance trade-off.

If you strip the #4 wire and immediately stuff it into the SB50 #6 lugs without any twisting, it will go in. Start at an angle and swing it into place! Usually, just a few errant strands need to be clipped.

I built and did the lug expansion but found it wasn’t needed.

My measurements from before show the differences, which matched the predictions well. Notably, the breakers and copper in the power panel become more critical at this level.

posts.name: Tanmay Darji
posts.cooked: If you switch over to 4AWG, I would recommend the WindyNation welding wire. It fits perfectly into the SB50 crimps with little effort and is highly flexible, which our team values. It’s amazing to work with.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
It depends on where your team is on the robot performance curve and how much budget you have to spend on this. ~90% of teams don't need to worry about it. Focus on getting your drive gearing correct—perhaps a bit conservative—and stick to L2 in the SDS system. Also, ensure your superstructure gearing is slightly conservative and pay attention to good practices around battery terminations, protecting wire paths to terminal lugs, and so on. Invest in processes and budget to prevent catastrophic failures rather than chasing small gains like switching to +3% efficiency. If you switch to 4awg wiring, it’s a strategic choice that should accompany other battery-related improvements, such as securing terminal lugs against side loads, connecting bolt connectors to the chassis, and similar measures. This approach was implemented by many teams after experiencing catastrophic failures in 2018, prioritizing long-term reliability over immediate performance gains.

**Key point:** A loose connection with 4awg wiring is just as risky as one with 6awg.

For ~9% of teams that already measure robot actions to tenths of a second, invest in fresh batteries, and build custom main power runs, incorporating 4awg in SB50s should be considered as a minor optimization. This setup can provide noticeable power increases without significant challenges and may help avoid brownouts. Our team successfully used this configuration from 2019 to 2024, and despite less aggressive drive settings and shorter sprints in recent years, we didn’t experience significant issues or brownouts.

**Important reminder:** While 4awg main power offers an accessible marginal gain, it’s far from essential for success. Only the most advanced teams might benefit from pushing to SB120s for an additional percentage point of performance.

In summary, prioritize proper gear ratios and electrical integrity to achieve reliable and consistent performance.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
People have said it before, but components like 4awg wire, SB120, and others often deliver only marginal performance gains. These upgrades alone are unlikely to significantly improve your team's performance in matches. For many teams, allocating resources to these items may not be the best use of their time and budget.  

However, I personally believe that investing in 8 new batteries each season and ensuring you have sufficient quality chargers to maintain both your primary batteries and practice batteries is a more worthwhile investment for most teams. If your team already has short main wire paths, secure battery connections, and reliable main breaker bolted connections in place, then upgrading to 4awg might be worth considering.  

Ultimately, whether an upgrade like 4awg wire is justified depends on the specific needs and resources of your team. You should evaluate how much value it adds compared to its cost, ensuring it aligns with your team's goals and performance objectives.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: I built and did the lug expansion, but found it wasn't needed. This year, I used a Banebot wheel hub with a set screw holding the flat end loosely, along with an arbor press and 1/4" pin for expanding SB50 terminals, which worked surprisingly well and allowed students to do it easily. I definitely feel that in games like last year's, 4AWG wire was helpful. This year, we might have managed without it. As mentioned earlier, I don't think wire gauge ranks very high on the list of important considerations for battery setup. The order from the battery presentation at Massive Mini listed these as among the least critical items. I'm interested in checking out the conference talk on this topic and incorporating any additional insights for our use this year.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
